Gosick. This show is a masterpiece and earned a 10/10 from me. The story is about a boy studying abroad post WWI in Europe, but his timing pretty much makes him an outcast. Kazuya Kujo doesn't seem to really care about it too much, which adds to his character of still being kind to everyone. It is here he meets Victorique de Blois and their friendship starts from there. It is a drama-packed, historical mystery.
Story~9
The story was superb, albeit taking it's time to start. It doesn't really hook you in until later in the series as the first few episodes mainly build up each characters'reputation and well as showing off skills to impress the audience. As you may have surmised, Victorique is a genius, who taps into her "Fountain of Wisdom" to solve mysteries to tackle her listlessness. We mainly see Kujo as her lapdog, simply doing as he is told and is often the go-between of Victorique and the rest of the world. However, as the story progresses, this third son of an Imperial General has to take on more responsibilities and is open to adversaries to protect the things he cares about. Even Victorique herself is very mysterious, dubbed the "Golden Fairy" of the schools' library. With his less than perfect sleuthing skills, but big heart, the story is also driven by an aspect of romance.


Art~10

One of the best animations out there, at least of its time, the art is elegant to reflect it's historical European setting. Aspects of Japanese interpretations of English and French watercolor is the main feature of the art, whilst keeping up with its Japanese art-syle, staying true to its anime roots. The attention to detail is great, though there are some quirks as with all mystery animations. In real life crime dramas, evidence is always in front of the detectives, though it is there duty to interpret the data. In Gosick, being an animation, evidence is simply edited in to the story after it is discovered, obviously because that is how easy animation makes it. It is not uncommon for mysteries to baffle even the sharpest of knives because of how animation is able to abuse its privilege of simply changing the scenes. It isn't as bad as Detective Conan where crime scenes are totally manipulating in the comically most convoluted ways possible. Gosick will leave its mark on viewers.


Sound~8

The music is great, as it is a drama mystery, so background music is very important for setting tone. Gosick does its' job delivering great music to accompany the delicate scenes as well as the important game changers. However, sometimes, these will be drowned out by the attention the audience pays trying to solve the crimes themselves. Thus, it serves its purpose , in a way, helping one focus. The anime also has its' own musical soundtracks that are semi-important to the plot. These songs help to aid transitions and convey emotions, to which they are made to appeal. If anything more was done, the show probably would have felt overdone, so it's good just the way it is


Character~9

The first few episodes serve to introduce the main characters with smaller subplots of various crimes. After that, the main story takes over, which still further develops the characters, even going into their personal histories. Development is abundant in this anime, and just about every character has an explorable backstory. There's even a reason why Victoriques exploitative older brother wheres his hair in a "french horn/unicorn" style(?). The characters are well done, especially Kujo and Victorique, especially as their relationship deepens. Villains have genuine motive and case-by-case every culprits' motive is calculated in a way that makes sense to the audience, instead of throwing facts together and hoping they work well together.


Enjoyment~8

Enjoyment is an 8 because I understand how the first few episodes may have deterred a few people away. A romance anime that didn't take off very quickly; crimes solved where the detective got no credit; set in a fancy school but seldom ever depicting scenes there and the list goes on. One you make it past the first two crimes, the mood is totally set. It'll make you want to watch everything all at once, because of how interactive mystery anime are by nature. Plus, the romantically dimwitted Kujo will leave everyone in either amused or bereft themselves, on how he handles his women ;] The overall plot deals with mystery in the sense that truths are hidden, not in the sense that a crime is committed and someone must solve it. However, by incorporating both, Gosick is created, combing both the child detective tropes and the "you know my name not my past" trope as well. The problem is not even that specific character know their past that much either. This gives way to another subplot of finding ones' identity in a seemingly cruel and manipulative world. This is important because it takes a good deal of memory to be fully immersed in this anime...


Overall~10

This anime is simply superb. the artwork and characters are great. the story, with all of its' subplots and oddities create a wonderful tale about friendship trying to survive at all costs, or the mysteries that will consume both main characters. Kujo and Victorique are victims of fate, but that very thing brought them both together in the first place. It is up to them to decide what they will do with their partnership and up to you the audience to find out what exactly that entails.

A great reviewer once said (paraphrasing here);
"You should never assume that a good show will stay good"
And that's Gosick in a nutshell.
Let's do the split subject thing and address each part one by one;
STORY
There is very little story to go around... the majority of the show is one long sequence of non-sequitour subplots that somehow lead us to a strange anti climax. There is no real overarching premise or plot that you could really call "A story". It sometimes pretends like its a romance but it isn't, it sometimes pretends like it's a mystery show but it isn't, it sometimes (laughably) pretends that it's anaction show but it isn't. Note that it is NOT a "Mystery show" in the vein of Detective Conan....  The viewer can never solve the mystery because we are not given enough information, but it masquerades as a mystery show which is fine because the subplot stories were at least somewhat interesting.   


In terms of setting it starts off as sort of a post WW1 pre WW2 (Mid 1920s Europe) pseudo mystery show with a pretty strong grounding in reality but then falls off of a cliff and becomes about "ELVES!!! MAGICK!!! SPLOSIONS!!!" completely ruining the setup it had created. World War 2 (Or what is its equivalent) occurs literally within a few minutes of an episode. They spent more time 'foreshadowing' it than anything.


Because the setting is all but abandoned and it has no distilled thesis; 

It is thread-bare plot with the flimsiest of justifications.




ART

Some of the locations , designs , backgrounds and objects designed for this show are beautiful... probably not period specific but still very beautiful and striking to the eye. I greatly enjoyed absorbing a lot of the lovely architecture , vehicles and even clothing. If you are the kind of person that puts a lot of stock in visuals, this show is a good investment of time... especially if you have an eye for detail.



CHARACTER:

There is only one character. Victorique (ka) Every other character is a "Caricature" or an inconsistent , ultra clichéd mess. The male lead (Kujo) is a complete joke.... he starts out assertive, as a proper foil to the overbearing Victorique but is quickly castrated to the point where he's just her foot-stool only after 1/3rd of the show has passed.


The other characters are little more then window-dressing for the interactions shared by Victorique and Kujo... but as I stated, since Kujo's characterization is inconsistent and clichéd, Victorique has no foil to bounce off of so she gets old fast (Unless you like one-man shows).


The characterization is incredibly poor across the board, we don't know why characters do the things they do almost during the entire show. The few character traits we get are very flimsy and do not justify the behavior of some of these characters. I do not want to spoil it but suffice to say, a great deal of the overarching 'plot' relies on "BWAHAHAHA /Mustache Twirl" characterization.




OVERALL:

I wanted to love this show because the setting is absolute dynamite (Post WW1, Pre WW2 Europe) and the pseudo mystery vibe it held  but it simply does not hold up. From a promising start it goes downhill fast eventually completely collapsing in on itself.


It is a terrible show that I do not recommend to anyone other than people that desperately want to see some lovely architecture and settings. The visuals are the only saving grace... but visuals alone cannot save this debacle.

Mysteries always seem to tantalize people's minds.  The idea of an unsolved murder case, or a missing valuable that has seemed to disappear out of thin air, or even the sudden reappearance of a supposed missing individual has always made people curious or intrigued.  And when you have an anime that combines the idea of mysteries solved by a gothic lolita that is the equivalent of an anime Sherlock Holmes?  Now, you've got something interesting.
Story (6.84/10):  After WWI, In the imagined country of Sauville, located somewhere on the edge of the Mediterranean sea, a Japanese boy, the third son of animperial soldier named Kazuya Kujo, better known as the Reaper that comes in Spring, is transferred into a prestigious academy where one day, he is told to go up to the library, where he meets our main female protagonist Victorique rolling on the floor out of sheer boredom.  And with this faithful encounter, the two embark on their fantastic journey filled with mysteries and stories.  


What I think is great about this story is the fact that it focuses purely on mystery and no other anime genre like supernatural or adventure.  The show features many little mysteries spanning about three or so episodes per mystery.  Each mystery ranges from something that is fairly straightforward to seemingly improbable or convoluted, each of them involving a ghost story or fairy tale that the made up country of Sauville is filled to the brim with.  For a good majority of the show, this is the formula that it follows, which actually worked well for the show, seeing how it mainly focused on mystery, but, in the last ten or so episodes, they scrap that idea for the sake of an "overarching" plot.  


The second half of the show I feel was mediocre at best.  It felt sort of forced upon when it came along, as the entire plot of the second half focused on a "villainous plot" that was rather generic and filled with flaws.  There was still the whole arcic setup of mysteries every so often in this second half, but they always seemed to take a backseat rather than be the focus point at the time.  


The pacing of the show felt a little bit off in some sense.  The second half of the show sort of just threw stuff at you and failed to fabricate a proper plot since there were a few plot holes and lack of explanation that I felt the show really could've used.  


The ending sort of felt rushed.  While we do get a rather happy ending whose result is up to the imagination of the viewer, it sort of skipped over a lot of things, essentially doing a four year timeskip that was well...weird.  It didn't feel like it coincided well with the story of the show and felt completely different from what we were presented at first, so it didn't have what I would call a pleasing effect.


Personally, I would've preferred the entire show to be its first half of mysteries because it was what we were presented with first, and it worked for the series in its favor.  


Overview:

+  Great first half

+  Good mysteries

-   Mediocre "overarching plot"

-   Somewhat rushed ending

-   Several plot holes


Characters (6.93/10):  Up first is the only character that you would probably care about in this entire series, Victorique.  Victorique is the singlehandedly most important character in this show, as practically EVERYONE revolves around her.  Being a rather smart girl the size of a life-like doll, Victorique is incredibly intelligent, solving mysteries by using her "wellspring of wisdom" to assemble the fragments of chaos and reconstructing how the action was committed, who committed the crime, and the motives, all while smoking a pipe before complaining how simple the mystery was and rolling on the floor in boredom.  What I love about her is how complicated of a character she actually is, where she can be cool and collected in one scene, then making cute kawaii faces in the next, before fuming in anger by puffing up her cheeks.  While Victorique is a very complicated and rather well made character, her castmates are well...average at best.


Kazuya Kujo is the main male protagonist in the series.  Kujo is a rather boring male protagonist, being the nice guy and trying to help out and protect the delicate princess.  Kujo's entire character is defined by Victorique.  Literally, everything he does is for the her sake, to the point that he would even sacrifice his own life for her.  While this is a commendable trait for his character, there is literally NOTHING else to him in terms of traits, so he's sort of unimpressive.  Plus, he says "VICTORIQUE!" like fifty times per episode, so there's a reason to be a bit tired of his character.


For the rest of the characters, they are split into two categories.  The first one being suspect characters, characters who are suspects to their perspective mysteries, and constant characters, characters who stay prominent in the series as a whole.  While the suspect characters get a pass due to the fact that get minimalistic screen time and only serve to push the mystery along, the constant characters don't.


The constant characters don't really have very much to them, as they are just generic character troupes that you can find pretty much anywhere.  We have the teacher who wants everyone to be friends, the secondary female who will never admit her feelings, and....ice cream cone head.  Aside from filling up the cast, and serving some sort of minimal role, the side characters were more or less made to exemplify Victorique and her importance to the story.  They basically improved her, whilst failing to improve themselves.


Overview:

+  Victorique

-  Generic main male lead

-  Generic side cast


Art and Sound (8.62/10 and 7.35/10): Gosick was created by Studio Bones, a studio that has notoriously been marked by a being very good at making very good looking animation, and this show is no different.  Gosick has a very detailed and very crisp and clear look to it.  Everything in the show is rather detailed and very nice to look at.  (Just look at the amount of detail put on Victorique herself.  She wears frills, a lot of them.  Imagine the amount of work needed to make her dresses, and she wears many different ones in the series.)


In terms of music, the show consists of 1 opening, and two endings.  Along with a very storybook-looking style for the opening's art, we have a track that I felt deserved to be listened to every time I watched this series because I felt like it had a very distinct sound that related to the fact that the entire series revolved around stories that related to the mysteries at hand.  It also sounds very whimsical and rather nice.  


On the topic of its endings, Gosick has two.  Each of them has its own sound with the theme of a melancholic tone that relates to Victorique's character.  While both of these endings are good in its own right, as they have their own unique sound and are not generic sounding in any way, I would've preferred the series stay with the same ending song like it did with its opening, as I feel as though the first ending sounds better and a bit more fitting for the series.  Don't change something that's already good, am I right?


Overview:

+  Very nice looking art

+  Good music

-   Unnecessary ending song change


Personal Enjoyment (7.11/10):  Like many people who've watched this series, I prefer the first half of the series due to the fact that it was what was presented first and worked towards the series's favor.  When the second half rolled in, the series felt sort of meh to me, as the story was somewhat broken and you're given information that unless you're Victorique, the fragments of chaos wouldn't make a whole story.  


On the topic of Victorique, I felt as though the series put WAY too much emphasis on her.  While yes, I agree that she is a fantastic character who boasts a lot of complexity and character all in a cute little package, the show made her too much of a focal point to the point that the entire cast relies on her for any sort of characteristics.  (They even go to the point of saying "Victorique presents" when they reveal the name of the show in the opening.)


I enjoyed this show's mysteries.  The fact that they created these mysteries that made me think a little bit, as well as making connections from one story to the next, making you pay attention to every detail for fear of missing anything later on, was a good and unique approach for the show.  But because this idea was scrapped for the sake of a more focused plot that put even more focus on Victorique, it didn't feel necessary and sort of made the show a little bit less enjoyable.  


Regardless, if you wish to have a good mystery show that is for the most part based on actual mystery, then Gosick is certainly the show to go forth, as the show has some rather good mysteries, and some pretty funny and memorable moments.  


Overall Score:  (7.23/10)

This is one of the few anime that I personally have approved of and given a score of all 10's across the board. 
This series itself presents a lot of elements that just added up to the masterpiece that is Gosick. Despite not understanding the title, the whole series was a rejuvenation of the traditional mystery genre mixed with dark secrets of its own.
Story gets a 10 out of 10. It starts out as a regular story with the main protagonist in a situation that he himself either cannot control or has done something that will start the process of the entire story. Now thisseries does something interesting from usual anime and involves history (although very minor, such as WW1 and WW2).  Although the series was based in a fictional country it still showed the interactions of people and places as if in actual history and life during that time period. Science was taking a big part in the world around that time and the argument of Magic VS Science was strong. Even though the series starts out like this it takes things gradually and smooths into each part of the story and connects different parts that would never seem to be connected. It goes from mystery of different murder cases then eases into mysteries connected with the main characters and then the plot is soon revealed.It was well drawn out, very suspenseful at times, and the ending was beautiful, a tear-jerking moment.


The Art work also receives a 10 out of 10. To break it down simply, the backgrounds from the school, the maze, the library and clock tower, and the characters were all drawn to detail, the mixed colors that stood out and gave the anime a beauty few can compare. Yes for most of the character they were not as impressive but different from the usual anime we see blonde hair, since this series takes place other than Japan for the majority. The individual characters are gorgeous. The main female has a lovely transformation as well. I will try to keep this review simple and concise. Please keep in mind that this is my first review and that it is not objective.
Story: 7/10
I initially went into Gosick expecting a Sherlock Holmes type mystery show set in the 1920s. Little did I know how far away from the truth I was. Gosick does have many detective style mystery solving arcs but they all make up a big political clusterfuck near the end. This was a very pleasant and unexpected turn of events that really makes Gosick stand out from your typical Scooby Doo type mystery anime. I can say with confidence thatI believe this is Gosick's strongest selling point. 

With that being said, there are several things that bothered me as well, notably the romance aspect of the show. I dont know how many people share this sentiment but I think this show would have been infinitely better without the romance, especially considering how cliché it was. I will further explain this point later on in the review


Art: 7/10

The art is pretty good but nothing to write home about either. For 2011, I would say it's normal and pleasant to look at. Aside from Victorique and Grevil though, most of the characters look like they could be pulled out of another anime. 


Sound: 6/10

I don't really focus too much on extra elements like sound and art unless they really stand out so please bare with me. The soundtrack, especially the OP and ED, are pretty nice but that's about it. IMO, there was nothing really noteworthy about the soundtrack but that might be because I usually don't pay much attention to it. Either way, it wasn't great nor bad, it was fitting and decent. 


Characters: 4/10

Now this is where, in my opinion, Gosick fails the most: the characters.

Let's start off with Kujo, a harem anime protagonist that somehow got placed into a political mystery anime. Just by looking at his appearance, you can tell that this guy will be your typical cheesy main character. He's basically just there to be the tolken Japanese guy with no personality that somehow manages to attract every relevant female character. He's generally useless expect for his role in helping Victorique grow as a character. Even then, one could argue that Victorique was more interesting before Kujo came along. At least before she wasn't  a damsel in distress every other episode. One thing that really boggled my mind was how smart the guy supposedly is but how he is so hellbent on becoming a solider! What the hell is that about? Why even go to study abroad then. However the worst part of it all is how often he says "Victorique". This kid can't go 5 minutes without screeching "Victorique". I mean for god's sake he probably says "Victorique" more often than Yuno Gasai says "Yukki" and I'm not even exaggerating! 

Next up is Victorique, the super smart loli that solves all these cases. Seriously, at the end of this anime there is a time skip and she's still a loli! I have no fucking idea why they decided to make her a loli, especially if they wanted to make a romance anime but fuck it. Anyways that's not what's important about her. Victorique, as a characters that was supposedly deprived from love and has the mind of a genius, was probably the most interesting. Nevertheless, she is a hardcore tsundere after Kujo comes and I personally despise tsunderes. For me, this made her insufferable at times. 

Then we have the supporting cast like Avril, Grevil and Cecil. Aside from one case, Avril is irrelevant and is basically an annoying third wheel. Grevil is your typical eccentric weirdo with a hairstyle( if you can even call it that) that would put the 80s to shame. And Cecil is just the funny and nosy sensei.

Nothing is really remarkable about the main antagonist either except that some of his actions made no sense although that's going into spoiler territory. 


Now considering the two MCs archetypes, one can see that this romance ends up being pretty generic. A tsundere and a cheesy naive male? Gee, I wonder how that will turn out! *cough*sarcasm*cough* 


Enjoyment:7/10 

Despite the shit I gave this anime for its characters, the main plot was pretty enjoyable and thrilling. It was especially satisfactory to see all the dots connected at the end. Yes the shitty romance and cliche ending did ruin some of it for me, but I tried ignoring it for the most part. 


Overall: 7/10

This is a solid anime, despite the clichés. I would recommend this anime to anyone looking for an interesting political mystery anime, so long as they can endure the romance and cheesiness that is.

Studio Bones knows how to make a good anime or at least an interesting one to say the least. This ranges from Full Metal Alchemist to the ever popular Soul Eater. Seasoned storyboard worker turned director for the anime Gosick was given to Hitoshi Nanba (Area 88, Captain Tsubasa).
Gosick is about a Japanese kid, Kazuya, moving to basically southern France (fictional place called Sauville) and happens upon a mysterious loli blond French girl in the upper library. Together they slowly form a sort-of friendship while solving various mysteries they happen upon.
It’s not often a mystery anime comes to light much like any within the horrorgenre. More often than not those anime fail to hit the mark and their various ways. Unfortunately, Gosick fall directly within the lines of this problem. A series focused on mysteries being solved either come off as ridiculous and implausible, or overly simplistic and unimaginative. The first mystery is solid enough, but as the series continues each new mystery seems worse and less interesting than the one previously. Besides, the loli known as Victorique and her banter with blank slated character Kazuya nothing really happens. Side characters often make nothing more than a cameo appearance to advance to the next mystery or what have you. Even driving forces behind the two main characters offer nothing more than what was told such as Kazuya’s father is rich and wants his son to succeed, no other personality or traits to be known or shown.\n\n
Apart from the character Victorique herself, there is not much to Gosick. Victorique runs the show by herself be it a wide evolving range or personality or even to the showmanship of her solving a weak told mystery. A saving grace are elements to each mystery carry over into the next instead of a “mystery-of-the-week” sequence. Not to say Gosick is totally saved from this, but it helps the show from falling completely into a bad rap. \n\n
Basically, Gosick has a decent main character in Victorique while the show suffers from mostly everything else. It will hit the viewer with a lot of imagery and crash land them into endless amounts of information that comes off as important, but amounts to nothing most of the time. It just is not a good mystery show worth recommending.

If you're looking for a good crime fiction anime, Gosick is not it. If you're looking for a historically accurate mystery anime, Gosick is still not it. Finally, if you're looking for an experienced reviewer, then this review definitely isn't the one you're looking for. 
This is my first review, actually, and it was prompted simply by how good this series is. 
Despite the wording of the synopsis, Gosick really is neither about ghosts or alchemists. Those are simply pieces in a much larger chess game. What Gosick really is about, is a romance between a most unlikely pair who become entangled in matters thatare far beyond their control. It is a story about power as much as it is a story about people. It is a story about hardship and determination.


Story: 10

Make no mistake, the nothing about this anime is perfect, but in my opinion, this is as close as it's possible to get. 


From the very first episode, from the very first, seemingly humorous and cheerful meeting between our protagonists, the story of Gosick has already begun. This anime has no fillers, no useless frames. Like pieces of a jigsaw puzzle, they fall together, and it's not until the very last few episodes of this show can you see the entire picture. Every single bit of seemingly useless information, every single fact of every minor arch, in fact ties in to the grand tale being told. If for this reason alone, I must give Gosick a 10.


However, there is much more to say about the Story. This anime has a great distribution of humor, angst, mystery and, most importantly, heart-warming romance.   The pacing, all series considered, is just about right and, finally, the ending fits the plot perfectly (no spoilers). 


For those of you who are here for the mystery, there is an ample amount throughout the anime, although it is true that the second half of the anime has far less than the first half. The mysteries themselves, however, are extremely well designed, in my opinion, and definitely reminded me of those old who-dun-it crime novels, or Sherlock Holmes shows. They have the same tricky cleverness, the same clues, and the same twisted endings that any crime lover is sure to enjoy.


For those of you who are here for the romance, you most definitely won't be disappointed. If you have watched Zero No Tsukaima and remember the part where Saito and Louis are separated for a time, well this anime gives you a similar feeling. For those of you who haven't watched Zero No Tsukaima, go watch it (after you finish Gosick, of course). Without giving anything away, hopefully, I will say that this series has one of the most satisfying, and somewhat more realistic, romances I've seen in anime.


Whew! So that was a LOT about the story, but to be honest I can go on and on about the other aspects for paragraphs too . . . but I won't, don't worry.


Art and Sound: 10

I put art and sound together for a very simple reason. I feel that the best art and sound should fit seamlessly into a show and you shouldn't notice it at all. It should add to the experience and not distract you, but amplify and enhance everything you feel. To that end, I definitely feel that Gosick achieves a 10. I'm not talking about the opening and ending songs, because if you like those you can just go on youtube or something and find them. The music you hear IN the anime, however, perfectly suit each situation, and the art is both detailed and realistic for the time it is set in. 


Character: 10

Character is a big one, and as odd as it sounds, I actually will say very little on the subject because there is simply so much to say. Every character feels three dimensional - that is to say, they feel like real people, as if this series was based on a real story. They change, they grow, and they find their way into your heart. There is not a single character in this show that I would say I dislike, except perhaps the villains. Even the villains I have to appreciate, for just how, well, villainous they can be, without sounding insane. 


Enjoyment, and thus Overall: 10

The best way to sum up everything I've said is like this: I'm sure this anime has its flaws, like every anime. However, after finishing it, I can't remember any of them. Gosick has an overwhelmingly beautiful story, portrayed by well designed art and sound, told through amazing characters. At no point in this anime did I look for flaws, because I was simply enjoying the tale. It took me so long to watch it because, to be honest, I wasn't sure about it after reading the synopsis, but I'm certainly glad I did. Gosick is definitely in my top 10 must watch list.

Problems and conflict are things that appear naturally throughout life. It might be annoying but one day you encounter one of these so called problems. You decide to solve it and eventually come up with an answer that you think is right and with this the problem is solved! If you think this is true than after watching Gosick you'll finally understand the reason why there is more than one answer to every question. GoSick is an anime that will take you on a series of twists in turns turning what you thought was right inside out and showing a the viewer another solution tothe problem.


Plot 10/10

At first glace GoSick might appear as your average murder mystery with our heroine, Victorique solving many of the mysteries using her amazing/unorthodox deductive skills with bits of comedy thrown in here and there. We'll if you thought this your wrong. As the story progresses suspense is thrown as you begin to see a larger conflict forming and within it the viewer starts to see how fates of all the characters intertwine and how everyone is connected to a bigger picture. One with everything that you thought was right turning out to be a wrong while at the same time leaving you with more and more questions. Finally when you reach the end where you don't know what to believe anymore all your questions are answered and everything is wrapped on beautifully with not a single scene being wasted throughout the series. During the last 20 seconds of episode 23 all I could do was stare at my screen and say amazing...


Characters 9/10

The plot is driven significantly with the help of the characters through the use of myths,fairy tails and other methods of story telling. For example when Kujo arrives at the school he becomes isolated from the rest of his classmates due to his black hair and dark eyes and gains the nickname, "The Dark Reaper" which is based on a ghost story. Victorique is also often described as a "fairy"" which comes from another story. And through this all the stories eventually come together the reveal many hidden secrets


The characters themselves are fun and easy to get used to in the beggining. You have your loli gothic detective Victorique who solves mysteries while at the same time bullying our protagonist and "Dark Reaper" Kujo. Throw in a police officer brother who takes advantage of his sister, a quirky teacher and busy body friend and you got yourself the making of an average anime but as their backgrounds are revealed and the mood begins to darken more characters are introduce and things arent what they seem too be.


Sound 8/10

The OP was the first thing to attract me to this Anime. It was catchy, fast-paced and something watch completely each week and shake my head to while singing along and I'm the type of person who usually skips the OP and goes straight to the actual show. Also throughout the entire series, the right music was played at key times to accompany the mood at that current time almost like magic, making it even more enjoyable. The EPs on the other hand where disappointing


Art 9/10

When you think art in GoSick the first thing that will pop into your head will be the backgrounds. All of them were well detailed and added to the enjoyment factor of the show. In some parts the effort put into the backgrounds made some scenes feel more realistic/believable.


Overall 9/10

GoSick is one of my all time favorite animes manly because the ending of the 2nd to last episode is probably something I'll never forget for a long time. Although people who love mystery would enjoy this alot, GoSick has many other elements that'll appeal to the viewer like the progression of Kujo and Victorique's relationship throughout the story and much more. I recommend it to anyone who has free time and needs something to watch.

Story:- First off, and this clicked around halfway through watching the show, note the date. 1920s pseudo-realistic (which I'll explain in a min) Europe. In fact, 1924, 6 years after WW1. What an interesting period to base an anime in. Anyway, much of the plot revolves around a young girl (well, as the last anime of the episode says, a girl with beautiful golden hair who is 16 but looks 10) called Victorique,or, as everyone else calls her, Victorikaaahhhhh! Yeaaahh, gets annoying after a while. Anyway, her "fountain of wisdom" is used to solve the typical "mystery of the week", some which are kind of "cop-outs", as they couldn't be solved WITHOUT the fountain, others are so simple a real 10 year-old could solve it. Anyway, in brief, the stories change every week with a new "mystery", and a "second story", not a story as such, is the devlopment between Victorique (kaaaaaa... etc) and Kujo, our other main protagonist. It's not bad, nothing special. 7/10.


Art:- The art is really nice, drawing on european designs of the 1920s, or gothic Victorian-style, shown in everything from Victorique (kaaaaa... OK, I'll stop) clothing to the academy where much of the story is based. Oh, better expain now why I said pseudo-realistic Europe. All of the story except a couple of middle episodes and the end (arguably the first episode for people who have watched the anime) is based in the fictional country Sauville, based in real-life Europe, on real-life Earth. One example of it being real-life Earth is because Japan as well as of course Europe in general is featured. The animation is also clean and crisp. A solid 8.


Sound: Sound is nothing special. There's nothing really of note, few escalating sounds in tense moments, but even the opening is nothing note-worthy. 5/10 (for at least being existant).


Characters:- Victorique has all ready really been done in detail. The other main protagonist is Kujo, a Japanese transfer stude... NO. Really?! Another Japanese transfer student story! *sigh* suppose this is a little more developed. He's really annoying and just a useless sop, only use being Victoriques servant. While this never stops (for reasons the last 5 mins of the show, um... shows), at least the second half he grows more as his bond with Victorique grows. I liked him then! These others are just of note. First, I can't remember her name, but Victorique affectiony refers to her as something like "Newt Fart". Seriously. She's basically just another love interest for Kujo, though it it is pretty one-sided on her part. Next is the good Inspector. I mean, this is a mystery-drama, a law-enforcement officer was going to crop up somewhere. Yeah, he just helps solve the mysteries, and has a relationship with Victorique whch I won't spoil. Another man with a relationship with Victorique is the Marquis. A Marquis is basically a nobleman, above the rank of Earl within the noble system. This means he has a lot of power, pretty much being His Maj's right-hand man. Both the Marquis and the King have very little to do in the first half of the story, they are known just have little screen time, and there power is really shown in the second half. Lastly, Victoriques mum. She has a name just can't remember haha... She helps flesh out the backstory and even out the male/female character ratio I guess. 8.


Final thought: I realise this is a long review so I'll keep it short. This anime ends in a lovely fairy-tale ending and re-inforces the whole show. Unfortunately, it does have its problems, this is the kind of show you can watch while talking to friends on facebook, or playing on your 3DS/PSP/iPhone etc. What I mean is, even with it not having a dub, the story doesn't demand your full attention, but it's also enjoyable enough when you don't want to do anything but watch a show. I hope this is a good indicator of my thoughts on the show. With that, Gosick recieves a very good 7/10, or 70%, or 70/100, or... etc etc.

It's one of those shows where my opinion on them and my thoughts on what it is about in the beginning and in the end are completely different. And yet, in a sense, are both correct.
It starts out as nothing that unusual: the two main characters are a usual boy and a girl who is super smart but socially awkward. They start solving mysteries together and their relationship progresses. "Oh, it's another one of those. So, they'll continue being friends, there probably will be a pseudo-love triangle and in the end they'll admit their affections. Hope the detective subplots are interesting, at the very least".These were my thoughts. Not entirely wrong, since show seemingly is arc-based and there even is a kinda-sorta-love triangle. Much to my surprise and joy, it turned out there's much more to this anime. Resolved mysteries come into play later (not all of them but most surprisingly do, one way or another), the characters evolve throughout the series, which applies not only to the main leads but also to a good chunk of the supporting cast. The relationship between the two is focused on but there is a surprising lack of padding. What I liked is they didn't really discuss it or explore it; they knew it was real and acted on it, which made it feel very believable and unique.


Which, again, surprised me, since the two leads aren't all that original. Victorique, say, looks exactly like Shinku from Rozen Maiden, save for her hair being a different type of blonde and the eye color, and even has a similar know-all attitude but, of course, actually cares for Ju- I mean Kazuya. He, on the other hand, is your typical kind and nice guy willing to sacrifice himself for others and so on. Most of their interactions involve her treating him badly on the surface while secretly caring for him, which is obvious to the audience and himself, really. He doesn't get it immediately (again, kudos to the writers for showing character progression) but pretty soon he stops complaining and just goes along with it, so this attitude, instead of resulting in a tedious and unfunny comedy routine, serves as a means to express Victorique's feelings indirectly, making the dialogues interesting to listen to. This is the soul of the anime, it builds up the bond between the leads while keeping things engaging, and I won't go into spoilers but boy, does it pay off!


None of the other characters are as developed, though most feel complete with just enough attention paid to them. I wish there was more of Brian Roscoe (I think the writers really like Christopher Nolan's movies; you'll get it when you see the twist with him) and less of Avril, who ended up being mostly pointless and rather cliched with her stereotypic girly personality. She's not prominent enough to become annoying, thankfully. The main villain, despite having no clear redeeming qualities, is good in that he has a realistic and a terrifyingly noble goal, making him, in the end, very believable and real. That goes for everyone in this anime, the baddies included - none are all that implausible and most of them are even identifiable. Again, not everyone, but most do have a legitimate reason behind their crime, be it passion, grief, friendship or fear. 


The crimes themselves are what I was concerned about at first. A detective seems to be the easiest genre to write; well, it's also the easiest to screw up. The answer can be too obvious, too complicated, too implausible or just plain impossible to guess. Not the case here. All the solutions are comprehensible and well-explained, none rely on mystical forces, in fact, the point that there's no such thing, instead, the science is what moves the world is made more than once. The creators make a point of showing all the details required to solve the mystery, so Victorique doesn't come out as a genius who spots things others don't: we know just as much as she. For me, it is an essential part of a good detective. So, even though they aren't what the show, in the end, is about, the subplots are entertaining to watch thanks to the intrigue.


Gosick has a rather unique atmosphere to it, most of it coming from the setting. The story takes place in a fictional country between France and Italy in 1924, which means shortly after the end of the first World War, which is acknowledged and referenced. This fact is interesting in itself, you don't see that much media attention being paid to the FIRST World War now. I also liked the architecture and the fashions which aren't modern yet but also don't feel entirely archaic. Speaking of the first World War, politics plays an increasingly important role in the show, so much so that the final episodes don't even have any mystery stories to them. Instead, they take a rather grim turn to show the second World War (in 1925; yeah, this part I still don't get), though mostly from the perspective of the main characters. Historic events are intertwined with their fate, which serves both as a story catalyst and a means to develop them. Overall, what starts out as a bright tale about a detective girl turns into a rather dark story deeply connected with the setting.


The music and the voice acting are consistently good, nothing to be said here. I especially liked the actress portraying Victorique, she did a great job keeping her appealing despite her rough attitude.


To sum up, it was a surprising and fantastic experience. A seemingly arc-based generic romantic comedy turned out to have a great plotline and discuss both World Wars, ultimately resulting in a satisfying experience complete with two great leads with believable chemistry. I can't find anything that's wrong with this anime.

Gosick is definitely a hooker from the first moment I watched it due to the twisted facial expressions that accompanies horror films. However, this turned out to be a pleasantly sweet mystery/romantic comedy, but that aspect, in my opinion, enhances the show and makes it more enjoyable. 
     The story is set in a fictional country, but drops hints of very realistic events such as war, oppression, class differences, racism, political greed, and more. Given that this is a mirror of some European country, the finer grains of sand from the aforementioned themes down to thecostumes(Victorique's dress!) speaks of Europe's very culture. I could believe there really is a country called Sauville in Europe if the author hadn't stated it didn't exist.


     The plot is the striking point, and this is where Gosick's charm comes in. The story makes use of creative schemes and tricks that haven't been used in a cliche manner in its plot, and although the ending of these plots are sometimes fairly predictable, the road to reach the ending is tortuous and presents a fun watch. The show does have some horror aspects such as twisted facial expressions and many deaths, especially in the first 3 episodes, but there is much less gore compared to some other shows. What I love most about the plot, however, is that every short story/plot lends to the major, overarching plot. The author integrated "history"  with unique and relatable antagonists and situations to create pieces of a puzzle that complete pieces of another puzzle that completes another puzzle. Kinda like those Russian nesting dolls that fit inside one another. 


     The characters are the next intriguing points. But at this point, you might be wondering why I gave it a 9 when all I spewed are compliments, so I'll say that I think the problem lies here. With such a realistic background and very believable events, the  characters make the story seem just a little fabricated, and Victorique is the main reason why. Don't get me wrong, Victorique is one of my all-time favorite characters out of all the anime I've ever watched(the way she pouts is so adorable) and I love the way they made her consistent(I've watched anime where the main lead is smart in one aspect and suddenly dumb in another) but the problem is that she's too smart. She figures out the correct solution to a problem when, in reality, there could be many possible resolutions, and personally, I find that a little hard to believe. It's like clicking C out of 4 answer choices and getting the question right when in reality there could be many right answers if you were asked to write a free response. She is also the solution to every problem: her Sherlock Homes out-of-world smarts is partially what drives the plot forward. I don't have a problem with that, but when the solution is almost formulaic...well. However, her personality is a solid all-time favorite and what I love most is her unique monotone way of speaking and her somewhat tilted way of humor. I didn't have a problem with Kujo's character; he's basically a remedy to Victorique's loneliness and he's silly and fun. They both had fantastic backstories, especially Victorique and Victorique's mother, and the other characters are well developed and add a dimension of depth to human nature. 


     Overall, this anime kept me wishing for more. Each mini plot was drastically different from its predecessors, which kept the anime from being repetitive, and all those plots nicely built up to an exciting and beautiful finale. The art and music complemented the tone as well. This show does have its flaws but it is very close to a perfect score. Through looking through the lens of this anime I can pick up an idea of what Europe might have been like in its older days and still enjoy everyday lives of students in an academy.

GOSICK is a detective / romance / mystery comedy anime.
The detective part is fun, the romance is very strong, the mystery was far fetched and weak and the comedy at times very funny.
The story follows Kojo a third son of an Imperial Soldier who attends St Magarittes Academy, a school for Europes wealthy elite in the fictional country of Sauville. Unfortunately he makes no friends because of his dark hair and eyes he is thought to be the "Black Reaper of Spring" from a local ghost story and will bring misfortune to everyone. Running an errand for his teacher to the school library he meetsVeronique (aka the Golden fairy / Grey wolf) an highly intelligent and perceptive but rude, stubborn and proud 16 year old girl with an overfondness of sweets who has a lolita appearance and seems to spend her time reading in the library as she is forbidden from leaving the school grounds by her aristocratic father. Together they solve mysteries and embark on a first strong friendship then romance where world events seem to be determine to tear them apart.


The first half, which is extremely fun, is about Kojo and Veronique getting to know each other and solving mysteries together. Despite her flaws Veronique becomes to depend on Kojo who despite Veronique's rudeness indulges her every whim, shows himself to be very resourceful and promises to find Veronique wherever she is, a promise he keeps. The second half is about the mystery of Veronique's birth, political corruption and war and the story has more plot holes than swiss cheese.


Kojo and Veroniques characters are very strong and without them the series would fall apart. Most of the comedy comes from Veronique when she is victim of her own pride and has brilliant expressions when she is angry. Watch out for her sarcastic laugh and when she gets stuck in a tree during a thunderstorm because she was too pround to admit she couldn't get down. This turns into a sweet moment when she tries and fails to impress Kojo by making a cup of tea.


The only other character of note is the half brother of Veronique, Gravil who is Sauville's greatest detective because Veronique solves all his cases for him and he takes all the credit. At first they appear that they don't like each other but later you find that this isn't true and Gravil tries to protect Veronique from the worst excesses of their father.


The two biggest problems are the plot surrounding Veronique's birth and secondary characters. A lot really isn't explained why she is so important to the Ministry of the Occult and her father's ambitions. Also the secondary characters are weak. Ok there is the teach and house mother, fine all good but Avril brings nothing to the series, Veronique's mother Cordelia was wasted and the mysterious Brian Roscoe remained mysterious and we didn't learn why he was in the plot.


Fortunately there was always the anchor of Kojo and Veronique to steady the  ship and the ending was perfect.


Overall a very good anime and Kojo and Veronique cancel out any weaknesses the show has although it could have been even better.

I'd say of all the anime I've seen in the past year and a half, this is the one that's tripped me up the most as to how much I love this anime. Part of me would say its a great anime, one of the best I've ever seen, while another part completely hates this anime. In my opinion, this anime pulled a Mass Effect 3 (I bet this is going to become a popular reference point). This anime was fantastic...for 22 episodes. The last two episodes, in my opinion, were extremely disappointing. Perhaps I should explain what my positives and negatives of this animereally were.


The thing I loved most about Gosick was the heartfelt, emotional character building that took place between the characters, primarily Kujo and Victorique. This anime did such a great job building the emotional bond between these two that it was beautiful...for 22 episodes. Although, it wasn't just them. Even seeing the interactions between Victorique and Grevil as well as Cordelia and Brian. Each interaction seemed well written, well acted, and built a tone that was well set throughout the anime. Even Avril Bradley, a character I couldn't stand, had her moments where I could tolerate her. 


Another thing I loved about this anime was the plot. It was really interesting. I've always been one that is interested in doing foreign exchange and on top of that, I'm sort of a history nerd. Combining the two made even more interesting with Kujo studying in 1920s Europe. Oh, and did I mention I'm a Sherlock Holmes fan? This plot was up my alley from day 1. However, going beyond that, I loved how the plot thickened (see what I did there?) when we learned more about Cordelia Gallo, Brian Roscoe, and both Albert and Grevil de Blois. How they were all connected to Victorique was amazing and (up through episode 22), I was enthralled with this story. There was only one major flaw with this anime and boy was it a major flaw...


The last two episodes. Oh man, were these a bummer. I know I'm supposed to refrain from spoilers, but I'll make you an offer. Through this next paragraph, I'll reveal some spoilers. Whether you've seen the anime or not, I'll leave to your discretion to read them. After this paragraph, I'll stop with the spoilers. I'm only pointing them out because they are the major flaws with the anime. Okay, here they are...


*SPOILERS*...In episode 23, after Victorique gets taken away by Grevil, Kujo goes back to Japan and joins the Japanese military...and they are at war. Now, I know this anime does flirt with European history (considering they even made up a fake country as a setting), but I wish they would've revealed what war Kujo was fighting in. The Japanese military was not very active during the mid-1920s. In fact, no military was really that active. World War I decimated Europe in the 1910s and there really wasn't a whole lot of conflict up until WWII (which wasn't until the mid-1930s). So I am VERY puzzled as to why Kujo was at war. Now, I will admit, this anime "hinted" at the coming Great War via Victorique's readings through the Fragments of Chaos. HOWEVER, they didn't really show that much happening between Saubure and all the other countries. To be honest, the whole topic of war in this story felt very forced. If this anime's setting was the 1930s, I'd be okay with it. HOWEVER, it wasn't. Plain and simple. Then, you have the final...battle?...between Cordelia and Albert. Someone who has seen this anime please tell me what the hell was this? Am I suppose to believe that an aristocrat and a 90 lb long haired, full dressed (literally, she's wearing a dress) can get into a full fledged ninja/samurai-esque fight? I think I might've actually chuckled at this scene even though it was supposed to be tense and dramatic. This felt WAY too unrealistic. The end result of the scene was actually very good, I won't argue against that...but the whole fight scene just felt really unnecessary. It really felt like the creators were going with the "hey, we need padding and we need entertainment...let's add a ninja fight!" Completely unnecessary and didn't fit the tone of this anime at all. FINALLY, and my biggest beef of all...THE FINAL EPISODE! This whole thing! It was...bad...well, not completely bad, but it certainly wasn't good. We practically learned the fate of all the characters in this anime throughout the whole episode...and Kujo and Victorique got practically the last 2 minutes. Really? The two main characters of this anime and you're giving them a whole 2 minutes for their reunion? Really?! Oh, but it gets better! Kujo comes back from years at war, Victorique goes through hell and back to get to Japan, so what happens when they see each other at the port? Meh, not much. They act like they just saw each other a few weeks ago. They built up all this dramatic suspense of the two being separated...and that's how they reunite them? By a hello and let's walk together underneath a cherry tree? Seriously, color me disappointed. To be honest, I didn't think the last two episodes were THAT bad...but it felt like the creators got so caught up in themselves with the final episode it was as though they looked at the clock and said, "oh crap, we only have 2 minutes left and we need to somehow squeeze in Kujo and Victorique's reunion!" It felt very rushed and I shake my head at the creators for the abysmal failure that was the final episode. *END SPOILERS*


*phew* Again, sorry for revealing so many spoilers in that last paragraph, but I did forewarn you if you didn't see the anime that I would be revealing some spoilers from the last 2 episodes. Overall, this anime was a fun experience. The dramatic suspense that this anime built over 24 episodes was really well done. However, there were moments during the final 2 episodes where I shook my head and couldn't believe the producers were going this route. While this anime was on the brink of being my favorite anime of all-time, the very ending of this anime felt like Mass Effect 3. It left a sour taste in my mouth and while the ending doesn't completely detract from the overall anime, it does sort of kill the buzz.

Gosick review 
Victorique is adorabaleand follows Kujo and Victorique as they either dive headfirst into the various ghost stories or legends that frequent their school and try to unravel the mysteries surrounding each . The main focus in this show is not on solving the mysteries but on the character interaction between Kujo and Victorique and how this interaction helps them solve those mysteries and get over the trouble they get in each time.


The pace of the show is slow  in the beginning we are introduced to the 1924 classic atmosphere , the picturesque peisage  of a mountain village, the old houses and buildings  architecture, the old steam train  and the people living in that village. The characters design and clothes are nostalgic and fit perfectly in the 20th century background peisage which the story is set in.As for small details Gosick excels at making them useful for the story and aesthetics  and captivates the minds and eyes of the viewer.  Another important fact is the development of the story and characters  it’s not set in a static place, we are always on “a moving  train” and the” stations” where the train makes a stop is our setting where our characters Kujo and Victorique solves the mysteries.The transition between those places is also done natural and according to the progression of the story and characters actions and influence.


The romance between those two is not rushed at all and it’s done according to the natural flow of the story. At first those two act like friends teasing each other , as the story progresses  we find more about our characters and their bond becomes more stronger. As each of them find about their story and circumstances  they began to develop feelings for each other  and became practically inseparable like two identical halfs  forming a whole.What’s impressive is the fact how those two work as a team to solve mysteries , Kujo with the labor work and Victorique with the brain, everything done  in a perfect synchro.The main concept this anime  abords is about human nature to be more precise the bond and trust between two strangers as in our case Victorique and Kujo. 


Gosick has some flaws that the viewer may notice along the development of the story for example some minor characters are casted away , victorique acting as a spoiled child in some situations, but that doesn’t  make Gosick a terrible show as a contradiction  it adds a tone of comedy to the show. Also the interactions and teasing between Kujo and Victorique is enjoyable to watch and the viewer can relate to real life situations.


Characters 6/10

The characters in Gosick are not that flashy and well developed but that doesn’t affect the story at all because Gosick focuses on the interactions between those characters and the influence they have on each other directly or indirectly.In one word the connection between characters and interactions  with each other make the story in Gosick.


Kujo  is the main character and a transfer student from Japan , he is known as “The black reaper who brings the spring” one of the folk stories from Saubure . He came to Saint Marguerite Academy  as a excuse to run from his problems back at home. His meeting with Victorique will change his life and decisions that he will make for his future. This influence helps in his character development and in accepting his past which is a tumultuous one.With this the show clearly puts in a spotlight the meaning behind “When you have someone dear to you to protect humans become stronger” which in this case Kujo from a crybaby becomes a man who everybody can rely on him.


Victorique  is our heroine , who solves mysteries with the help her friend Kujo. Most of the time she  likes to act  as a spoiled  little child who needs attention , and tbh the repetitive use of this attitude kinda annoyed me.  Her character development is also influenced by Kujo and the interactions between them across the flow of the story. She is arrogant and has a typical tsundere reaction evidentiated by her reaction around Kujo , she hits him when she is in a bad mood. Also she has a soft part too and cares about the bond between her and Kujo and she is always happy when Kujo visits her and brings her sweets  in exchange for solving the mysteries. 


Other minor characters help with the development of the main characters Kujo and Victorique but there are used as plot devices for the progression of the story and casted away after their job is done.

The villain is the typical greedy one who thinks only for his own benefits and earnings and likes to sacrifice people to achieve his goal. He is the weakest piece in this puzzle called Gosick and even after his story and circumstances are presented the viewer can’t agree with his actions and will only result in a flaw for the anime. 


Animation 9/10

The characters design and the stunning 20th century peisage captivates the mind  of the viewer from the first episode to the last.The small details crafted into the buildings and characters are well done.


Sound 9/10

The sound and opening song are good , the ost used fits perfect in the classic atmosphere of the 20th century.


Enjoyment  9/10

Even if some moments may seem annoying and the villain is a joke this show clearly is enjoyable especially the character interactions is fun to watch how they tease  each other. Also the ending is a good reward for those who love romance anime and you won’t be disappointed at all.


Overall 8/10 

The mix of comedy and drama and the transition between those two is executed well by the characters interactions and influence on each other. It’s a enjoyable classic romance story set in a nostalgic 20th century environment which  adds elements of comedy and mysterie to make it more appealing for the viewer.

Gosick has something for everyone. Romance? Check. Drama? Check. Mystery? Check. Action? Check. Ecchi? … Well, I guess not. 
It is 1924 and Kujo "enrolls" in a study abroad program to attend St. Marguerite Academy, which is located in the fictional European nation of Sauville. Nicknamed the "Grim Reaper" for his black hair and (conveniently) black school uniform, Kujo struggles to fit in amongst his classmates until he goes into the school library and meets a rather short girl named Victorique De Blois. Little did he know that he will soon become Victorique's manservant. Victorique doesn't go to class but she reads books all dayin a Hogwarts-esque library. So, she is constantly bored and she begins to nag Kujo to bring her interesting stories. With her self-proclaimed "wellspring of wisdom" and Kujo's adventurousness, the tag team begins to uncover convoluted mysteries in Sauville that some people have thought were unsolvable. 


Saying anything more would deprive you of the epic rollercoaster ride that is Gosick. This anime has many interesting twists and turns that keeps you on the edge of your seat. However, Victorique seems to have unraveled the mystery before it even begins. It doesn't seem like any of the mystery is a challenge to her and perhaps those of you who are searching for a slightly less over-powered main character may be disappointed. The anime does have many dark elements to it: grisly murders, ghosts, and overzealous cults. Thrilling as they may be but if you are someone who watches scary films with a pillow in front of your eyes (like me), avoid watching Gosick at night. 


Although Gosick is listed as a romance anime, the romantic aspects don't come through until the latter half. However, this allows for the writers to meticulously build up the relationship between the main characters and have it all release towards the end. This is one of the aspects that the script got it right. Many times, the romance seems to pop out of the blue or poorly expressed but Gosick takes a very logical approach to developing the romantic dynamics. While the romance cannot compare to drama/romance anime, it is nevertheless very satisfying to experience.


There is a lively cast of characters in Gosick and there is not one character who seems to be out of place. As he proudly calls himself, Kujo is the third son of a Japanese Imperial soldier. He is pretty light-headed but when his partner Victorique can't think straight, he picks up the slack. For me, Kujo is an annoying character because he's like a fly in a room. He aimlessly wanders about and gets himself into trouble despite Victorique warning him. Thankfully, he's brave and stubborn because that gets him out of many situations. 

Victorique is the female lead and she is a fascinating character to watch. She has the personality of a rock but when given candy, she can turn as cute as a puppy. Her character development can be neatly described as peeling an onion. Every episode of Gosick is peeling off one layer of Victorique's character until we get to the very end. Indeed, what's at the center of the onion is very delicious.

Grevil De Blois is an inspector who is very well-known in Sauville for solving seemingly unsolvable mysteries. Of course, we all know who his consultant is. He sports a narwhal hairstyle and is pretty much arrogant all of the time. But similar to Victorique's character development, we get to eventually see his true personality.

There is also Avril, who is one of Kujo's classmates and is jealous that Kujo constantly spends time with Victorique. She is mainly there for comic relief but she does get involved in a mystery. 

There are many more characters but they are gradually introduced in the story. This is what makes Gosick very exciting: new characters constantly join the party.


The music was very good. The background music was similar to listening to symphonies: lots of strings and brass. The OP was solid and the first ED was very catchy. You probably would find yourself singing the first few lines whenever it starts to play. The voice acting was also very well done, especially Victorique's voice actor. The feelings that were heard through her voice in the last few episodes were amazing. 


The art and animation was well-done as well. The background scenery were incredibly detailed and all the characters had their unique style. Bones did the animation and they also did Noragami, Full Metal Alchemist: Brotherhood, and Soul Eater. Indeed, they can produce some solid art.


Overall, this anime kept me wanting to know what happens next until I was very disappointed to know that I had reached the final episode. If you are looking for a solid anime, give Gosick a try! Perhaps the only people who wouldn't like Gosick would be those who hate plot twists. Also, it would be very interesting to see what happens if the characters in Hyouka, especially Oreki, met Gosick's cast. Oh how many more mysteries will there be?!


Let me know how you thought of Gosick! Did you have a favourite mystery? I would love to hear from you!

Every now and then a show, doesn't particularly have to be an anime, comes along that sweeps you off your feet and engrosses you in another world. The Last Air Bender, Le Chevalier d'Eon, Tetsuwan Birdy Decode, So Ra No Wo To, and now Gosick. I personally have always been a fan of movies and shows that take you from one place and drop you at another by then end of it. Especially if that place is time itself. Shows and movies that follow a character or a set of characters across several years are hard to find, but almost all of them are executedbrilliantly. A few examples would be Forrest Gump, Rin, and this anime falls among them.


Story


I'll admit I did not expect this story to go where it went or to reach as far as it did. You start the series feeling one way and by the time it's over you have a completely different feeling in the pit of your stomach that won't go away. The story centers around Victorique and Kujo; two characters who are bound to one another by a very strong bond that is near unbreakable even with the interference of some side characters. The two spend the majority of their time solving individual mysteries that at first seem unconnected or random, and can lead you to believe that the entire series will resemble this. In fact I half expected them to solve small mysteries up until the final 6 or 7 episodes and then suddenly there's this larger plot that they have to take on. I also expected it to have a cliche, cookie cutter, happy ending with a long speech given by Kujo about his morals and ideals. Fortunately this is not the case. The overarching story is ever present even though you might not notice at first. But slowly as they solve more mysteries the pieces are put together. Everything in the series happens for a reason and the reasons are generally quite profound. When all is said and done you will think that you started watching Gosick, but somehow ended up watching grave of the fireflies. The last remaining piece of the story that really drove me to keep watching was it's constant tie to history. Not just putting the characters in some fantasy universe created solely for this show, but tying them to the real world as well. Similar techniques can be seen in the aforementioned examples (Forrest Gump, Rin).


Art

The landscapes were breathtaking in almost every scene. The characters fit into each panel so well you would think they were painted in. Everything was fluidly animated and didn't stretch the boundaries of the imagination. There wasn't much action, but when it did arise it was very well done.


Sound

A great soundtrack that moves you at every turn and does a fantastic job of driving the story and the minimal action and suspense forward.


Character

Though I pretty much already summed this up I'll give a quick overview and fill in some points I hadn't mentioned before. The characters were very well developed and seemed to have deeper connections to this fabricated world than merely existing there. Each character had some small story to tell. Whether it be Sophie and the slightly dim-witted teacher who had been friends for 10 years or Avril who wanted to become an adventurer like her grandfather and who was also in love with Kujo. All of the characters recieved attention even if they only appeared for an episode or two.


Enjoyment

Every person will enjoy this to a different degree, but I can wholeheartedly say that every person will enjoy this series. It's almost impossible not to.


Overall

A great series that will leave you begging for more by the end. I love the style, the era, the characters, the art; Everything drives me to wonder if there will be a second season. Though another season would be nonsensical.

There are few stories I can immerse myself in. There are even fewer that cause me to delay and delay finishing solely because I don’t want the story to end. Sometimes it’s because I can relate, other times it’s because I like the dialogue, prose, characters. Others ooze a certain vibe or atmosphere that hits me in just the right spot. Gosick, with its combination of gorgeous artwork, endearing main characters and a delightfully victorian gothic (but in the 1920s) type storyline, was one of those series that managed to crawl its way into my heart from the beginning.
The anime’s first half is fairly episodic,establishing the relationship between Kujo, the “Black Reaper” from Japan, and Victorique, the “Golden Fairy” who resides at the top of a tower-like library. Victorique is a master of mystery, able to solve any case thrown her way by the somewhat eccentric Inspector de Blois, and Kujo, having become Victorique’s unofficial helper, goes along for the ride. The cases sometimes span one episode, and sometimes two-three in mini-plot arcs drenched in Sherlockian intrigue. That is, until the cases delve into a more personal flavor, sprouting questions regarding Victorique’s origin, present and intended future.


Gosick’s atmosphere holds up the fun, delicately whimsical characters against a progressively more gothic story that is positively charming in a darker sense of the word. The artwork in the opening credits help to establish a fairy tale quality to the atmosphere, with the musical score lending power to the story’s mood. The comedy is [mostly] well-timed, allowing the viewer to breathe between darker moments and not feel crushed under some overly heavy-handed drama.


Of course, almost every series has its drawbacks. Some of the fight scenes near the end felt cheap and far too, well, anime to be a part of the setting that had been so well established. There were some overly silly moments that felt unnecessary and frustratingly mood-shattering. Fortunately, the silly comedic moments were pretty few and far between, and the craziness of the ending fight scenes did not subtract from the wonderfully climactic build of the final episodes to a charming and heart-warming ending to tie it all off with.


For those searching for something a little different dipped in a dark fairy tale while shrouded in history (despite the few liberties it takes with historical events), Gosick is a delicious treat.


Any constructive feedback is appreciated.

Gosick is, to be honest, a very strange anime. Not strange as in weird or creepy, like Madoka, or even something you may have to watch multiple time, like FLCL, but it's strange because not every part of it necessarily fits together. And that's going to turn some people off.
Story: 7
I'm sort of torn on the story. If you were to summarize the story into one sentence, it would probably go something like: "Gosick is aboutan extremely smart young girl and a Japanese boy who solve mysteries using science," or something. Now, this is all fine and dandy, even if it is a bit absurd. Many of the cases tackled are solved using a string of logic, meshing the small bits of evidence together to solve the case. It's not a particularly bad way to do it, but it's not particularly good either, as some of the cases  can become pretty confusing if you're not paying attention well enough. The small bits of evidence also don't hold up as well as the bits of evidence in say, Phoenix Write or similar more-standard detective/mystery stories. However, the cases are relatively enjoyable, even if you can see the end (or parts of the end) to some of them. However, being able to guess the end of a case is not a bad thing, as it makes everything a little more believable. 

However, it quickly takes the turn of becoming a romance anime, again, something which isn't necessarily bad. I personally didn't mind it, though most of the romance is very stereotypical. Just be warned, though, if you don't like romance in your mystery, do NOT watch Gosick.

At its end it is a romance anime, not a mystery anime, which, as I said before, may turn people off. However, if you take off the last episode, you have a mystery ending. While it doesn't make the cop-out of "all these cases were one huge conspiracy!", the cases themselves aren't connected all that much, save the end two. Each could probably exist separately, and it wouldn't have made a lick of difference.


Art: 8

Sound: 8

Again, not a whole lot to say. The sound itself is pretty standard. The music is decent, though I prefer the first OP/ED to the second. However, the game takes place in a French-speaking country, but the anime is in Japanese, of course. Normally, this wouldn't be a huge problem (like with anime that take place in English-speaking places), but there are a few times where the main character's Japanese heritage and language are referenced, which make the whole thing feel slightly awkward. Of course, I can't think of a way to fix this without changing the whole thing, so I won't be too harsh in score about it.


Characters: 7

If you've read some of the more negative reviews on MAL, they mention how absurd the main female character (Victorique) is. How preposterous it is that a 12-year-old is outwitting practically an entire country's police force. However, it's not particularly "magical," nor is it particularly absurd. If you take a sliding scale from "average" people to, say, savants, Victorique would be  less "average" and more "savant." While she doesn't particularly lack many social skills, she does possess a very high intelligence, which isn't really all that strange. She simply follows a better string of logic, and is better at finding clues and relevant information than most of the characters in the story. That's all there is to it. No magic. No weirdness, and actually sort of grounded and reality. I found it pretty believable, in that respect.

Now, on to the rest of them. This is probably my biggest problem with the show. Every main character (and even the side characters) have personalities more fitting to a modern-day setting. I'm not saying ditzy klutz teachers and egotistical drill-hair detectives didn't exist in the early 1900s, but they just seem unfitting. However, I do get that historical accuracy does sometimes need to be sacrificed to make the characters interesting, but I think it could have been done a little more gracefully.


Enjoyment/overall:

I think it has enough for most people to enjoy some part of it. So, as with anything, try it for a few episodes. If you end up not loving it, and find it a drag to keep watching, you don't have to finish it. We're not going to cut off your head or burn you alive or anything.

The father is one of the most irritating and most disgusting villains I’ve ever seen. Some villains can be so irritating but at the same time they can also be admirable with their principles and beliefs on the purpose of their actions. But the villain here is plain disgusting. It is ironic that he is one of the most disgusting villains when he is so related to the main protagonist. I guess, the fact that he is related makes him a lot more disgusting. Kujo is the typical male lead partnered with tsundere types who just follow and quietly receives verbal and physical abuse. He understands and sees through the tsundere façade of Victorique. Most of the time his type of character has the tendencies to become so cheesy or too dramatic but for some reason he is not irritating at all. What makes him different from that typical character is that he is not indecisive. He knows what he feels and would not hesitate to show it. Victorique’s character is cliché as well. The typical tsundere type who would not say what she truly feels and bosses around. Your everyday queen-like character that gets what she wants from the male lead. But like Kujo, she is also not irritating at all. Tsundere types have the tendencies to become so irritating because they’re not so honest attitude always makes misunderstandings. However, despite not being honest with her true feelings, she would still show it if needed and would immediately realize to just show how she truly feels. Despite the queen-like attitude, she never throw tantrums or just give up in dire situation, but rather she would suck it up and be strong enough in order to keep on living. I admire her so much for being strong and staying sane despite everything that has been happening to her life but at the same time I feel sorry for her as well, for having such father. If I were her, I would feel so disgusted just by thinking that my father’s blood runs inside me. I love the relationship between the protagonists. Their romance is not overly done that would make it so cheesy. Simple gestures, sweet actions, and very touching feelings towards each other are all needed to show the amazing romance of these two. 


About the ANIMATION 

As one of the latest series, the animation of this anime is one of the top. The illustration of one beautiful part of Europe is so beautiful. The characters are very well-made as well. The seiyu’s voice is so perfect for Victorique. It genuinely brings out the character. Well, her seiyu is known voicing these types of amazing characters and she does it so well. 


This is anime experience I will never forget. This is the very reason why I am in love with animes and mangas. More than just being entertained, I experience something so wonderful which make me feel so thankful that I am living in this type of world where such creations are being made.

In my expierience in mystery animes, this one is different then most. Gosick is more of a romance mystery. Victorique De Blois, daughter of Cordelia, is a stubborn girl. Her friend Kujo is a sweet boy that always has something for Victorique. He puts up with her most of the time. Those are the two main characters and I'll say no more characters so I don't spoil anything. Though I'm glad the ending was the way it was. The only thing I didn't exactly like was how sad Avril would get when Kujo acted nice to Victorique. Other then that, it was a wonderful anime.
